key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
• Trade mark infringement and cancellation of registration.
• Powers of Registrar under Section 57(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1999 to cancel or vary trade mark registration.
• Grounds for cancelling or varying a trade mark registration (contravention, failure to observe condition etc.).
• Scope of registrar's power to rectify the register under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act 1999.
• Effectiveness and enforceability of registered trade marks in specific services industries (e.g., transmission, reception & sharing of digital data).
• Service of notices on respondents and their obligations under law.
• Validity and scope of registered trade marks vs. actual market activity and goodwill.
• Legality of trade mark registration for multiple categories of services.
• Territorial jurisdiction and competence of the High Court to hear rectification petitions.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary:**

This is a rectification petition filed by Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited (petitioner) against VNOW Technologies Private Limited and Anr. (respondents) under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act 1999.

**Background:**
The petitioner has sought rectification of the register of Trade Marks for removal of the mark "VNOW" from services in respect of which it stands registered, assigned to respondent 1. The matter originated before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB), where notice was issued on the petition on September 28th, 2020.

**Legal Issues:**
The petitioner has raised several legal issues, including:

*   **Grounds for rectification:** The petitioner has alleged that respondent 1's registration as a proprietor of "VNOW" trademark is contrary to Section 2(1)(m) of the Trade Marks Act 1999.
*   **Services covered by trademark:** The petitioner contends that the services covered under "VNOW" are not limited to transmission, reception and sharing of downloadable digital data and content but also extend to providing access to GPS/LBS/other navigation services, communication network, web casting/online/offline services for transmission or reception of audio/video/data files & content, etc.

**Arguments:**
The petitioner's Learned Counsel has argued that the respondent 1 does not provide only specific services as set out in their response but also offers a broader range of services. They claimed that respondent 1 is involved in other business activities and hence using "VNOW" for an unrelated line of business to what was initially proposed as well as its usage which is widespread including in respect of transmission, reception and sharing for the purpose data communication including data transmission.

**Court Findings:**
The Honorable Justice C. Hari Shankar of the Delhi High Court has observed that:

*   **No evidence provided by respondent 1:** Despite the service of notices before both IPAB and the High Court, Respondent No. 1 has been persistently absent throughout these proceedings. The Learned Justice further noted that they have not filed any counter-affidavit despite being put to notice.
*   **Evidence on record:** The court noted that there is no documentation proving services were provided under respondent 2 by R 1.

**Decision:**
In view of the lack of evidence from Respondent No. 1 and their consistent absence, Justice Hari Shankar finds in favour of the petitioner's case:

1.  **Rectification of register:** The Honorable court orders rectification of Register in respect of trademark 'VNOW' owned by Respondents.
2.  **Services beyond scope:** Petitioner's contentions that respondent's assigned services are within their scope was found valid by the Delhi High Court and thus the court accepted petitioner's argument.
3.  **Section 2(1)(m) contravention:** Due to respondent's non-appearance the learned Justice has considered all arguments presented by the counsel of petitioner.

Given the complete evidence in hand, the order is passed in favour of the applicant (beneficiary).

The petitioner claims to have adopted the mark „NOW‟, as a 
distinct and dominant part of its various marks aforesaid in 2004 and 
commenced use of the said mark as part of the mark „TIMES NOW‟ 
in 2006. Times Now, as is well-known, is a news channel which 
attracts considerable viewership and is viewed both within and outside 
the country.  Following the success of Times Now, the petitioner 
launched a business news channel under the mark „ET Now‟ in June 
2009.  Closely following thereupon, „Movies Now‟ as a television 
channel featuring Hollywood films, was launched by the petitioner in 
2010, „Romedy Now‟, a television showing romantic and comedy 
Hollywood films was launched in September 2013 and „Magic Bricks 
Now‟, a television channel providing information with respect to real 
estate and property was launched on 31st October 2015.   Magic Bricks 
Now was renamed Mirror Now in 2017.

The petitioner felicitously refers to the aforesaid marks „TIMES 
NOW‟, „ET NOW‟, „MOVIES NOW‟, „MIRROR NOW‟ and 
„ROMEDY NOW‟ as “the NOW centric trade marks”.  By dint of 
continuous usage as well as the rights that accrue in favour of the 
petitioner consequent to the aforesaid registrations held by it, the 
petitioner asserts that it has exclusive rights to use the expression 
„NOW‟ as any part of a trade mark in respect of services relatable to 
Class 38.  The petition also avers that, owing to the reputation that the 
petitioner‟s services have garnered over time, the afore-noted 
registered trademarks of the petitioner are entitled to be regarded as 
„well-known trade marks‟ within the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg)2 of 
the Trade Marks Act.

10. 
Having heard Ms. Mamta Rani Jha, learned Counsel for the 
petitioner, and perused the record, it is apparent, from the record, that 
the petitioner has registrations, in its favour, of several marks which 
involve „NOW‟ as the latter part of the mark, under class 38.  The

3 11.  
Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark. 
(2)  
A trade mark which –  
(a)  
is identical with or similar to an earlier trade mark; and 
(b) 
is to be registered for goods or services which are not similar to those for which 
the earlier trade mark is registered in the name of a different proprietor, 
shall not be registered if or to the extent the earlier trade mark is a well-known trade mark in India 
and the use of the later mark without due cause would take unfair advantage of or be detrimental to 
the distinctive character or repute of the earlier trade mark. 
(3)  
A trade mark shall not be registered if, or to the extent that, its use in India is liable to be 
prevented –  
(a)  
by virtue of any law in particular the law of passing off protecting an 
unregistered trade mark used in the course of trade; or 
(b)  
by virtue of law of copyright. 
***** 
 
(10)  
While considering an application for registration of a trade mark and opposition filed in 
respect thereof, the Registrar shall –  
(i)   
protect a well-known trade mark against the identical or similar trade marks; 
(ii)  
take into consideration the bad faith involved either of the applicant or the 
opponent affecting the right relating to the trade mark.

„NOW centric‟ marks of the plaintiff, merits acceptance.  
 
11. 
That proprietorial rights can emerge even from a family of 
marks held by a registrant, in which part of the marks may be 
common, stands recognized by a Division Bench of this Court in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala v. Shree Vardhman Rice & General 
Mills4, which has been followed by another Division Bench in 
Kirorimal Kashiram Marketing  v. Shree Sita Chawal Udyog Mill5. 
One may usefully reproduce, in this context, para 18 of the report in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala4: 
“18.  
It is not possible to agree with the reasoning of the learned 
Single Judge that the word QILLA is not associated with rice and 
therefore no ordinary purchaser of rice would associate the 
Defendant's mark as that of the Plaintiffs. It is plain from the 
pleadings that the Plaintiff has been using the words QILLA 
consistently in connection with the rice being sold by them with 
only the first word indicating the colour viz., GOLDEN, LAL or 
NEELA. It must be held that the Plaintiff has been able to prima 
facie show that it has developed a ‘family of marks’ and that by 
merely changing the first word from GOLDEN, LAL or NEELA to 
the word HARA there is every possibility of confusion being caused 
both in trade and in the mind of any person desiring to purchase 
rice. Likewise the use of the picture or depiction of a fort in the 
background on the label/packing of the rice is also likely to cause 
confusion in the mind of the purchaser and in the trade that the 
product being sold by the Defendants are in fact those 
manufactured by the Plaintiff.” 
(Emphasis supplied) 
 
In a similar vein, the High Court of Bombay, in Neon Laboratories 
Ltd v. Themis Medicare Ltd6, held the “XYLOX family of marks” 
comprising XYLOX 2%, XYLOX HEAVY, XYLOX GEL, XYLOX 
ADRENALINE and XYLOX 2% Jelly to be infringing the “LOX 
family of marks” comprising LOX 2% ADRENALINE, LOX 4%, 
LOX 5%, LOX HEAVY 5%, LOX VISCOUS, LOXALPRIN, 
LOXALPRY, LOXIMLA, PLOX and RILOX. 
                                          
4 ILR (2009)VI Delhi 399  
5 AIR 1963 SC 449

By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021

12. 
The „NOW‟-centric „TIMES NOW‟, „ET NOW‟, „MOVIES 
NOW‟, „MIRROR NOW‟ and „ROMEDY NOW‟ marks constitute a 
“family of marks” within the meaning of the concept as understood in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala4 and Neon Laboratories6, especially as 
they cover services provided in the same Class 38.   I will refer to the 
registered trade marks of the plaintiff, therefore, as “the „NOW‟ 
family of marks” hereinafter, instead of “the „NOW‟-centric marks”. 
 
13. 
Section 17(1)7 clarifies that the proprietorial rights conferred by 
registration is for the mark as a whole.  In other words, the rights 
conferred on the petitioner by the registrations held by it in respect of 
the NOW family of marks are over the TIMES NOW, ET NOW, 
ROMEDY NOW, MOVIES NOW and MIRROR NOW marks as a 
whole in each case, and not for the mark „NOW‟ per se.  Section 
17(2)(a)8 makes matters clearer, by disentitling exclusivity in respect 
of part of a mark which is registered as a whole.  This has, over time, 
come to be known as “the anti-dissection rule”.  
 
14. 
The registrations held by the petitioner in the „NOW‟ family of 
marks confers, therefore, on it, rights to claim exclusivity in respect of 
each of the marks as a whole, and not in respect of the „NOW‟ part of 
each of the marks.   
 
                                                                                                                   
6 (2014) 60 PTC 621 
7 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
8 (2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark –  
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-distinctive 
character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the whole of 
the trade mark so registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 10 of 19 
 
15. 
The anti-dissection rule is, however, subject to a caveat, 
elucidated thus by Pradeep Nandrajog, J. (as he then was), speaking 
for a Division Bench of this Court, in South India Beverages Pvt Ltd 
v. General Mills Marketing Inc.9: 
“19.  
Though it bears no reiteration that while a mark is to be 
considered in entirety, yet it is permissible to accord more or less 
importance or „dominance‟ to a particular portion or element of a 
mark in cases of composite marks. Thus, a particular element of a 
composite mark which enjoys greater prominence vis-à-vis other 
constituent elements, may be termed as a „dominant mark‟. 
 
20.  
At this juncture it would be apposite to refer to a recent 
decision of this Court reported as Stiefel Laborataries v. Ajanta 
Pharma Ltd10.  The Court whilst expounding upon the principle of 
„anti-dissection‟ cited with approval the views of the eminent 
author on the subject comprised in his authoritative treatise-
McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition. It was 
observed: 
 
“41.  
The anti-dissection rule which is under these 
circumstances required to be applied in India is really based 
upon nature of customer. It has been rightly set out in 
McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition about 
the said rule particularly in Para 23.15 which is reproduced 
hereunder: 
 
23.15 Comparing 
Marks: 
Differences v. Similarities 
 
[1]  
The Anti-Dissection Rule 
 
[a]  
Compare 
composites 
as 
a 
Whole 
: 
Conflicting composite marks are to be compared by 
looking at them as a whole, rather than breaking the 
marks 
up 
into 
their 
component 
parts 
for 
comparison. This is the “anti dissection” rule. The 
rationale for the rule is that the commercial 
impression of a composite trademark on an ordinary 
prospective buyer is created by the mark as a whole, 
not by its component parts. However, it is not a 
violation of the anti-dissection rule to view the 
component parts of conflicting composite marks as 
a preliminary step on the way to an ultimate 
determination of probable customer reaction to the 
conflicting composites as a whole. Thus, conflicting 
                                          
9 (2015) 61 PTC 231 
10 211 (2014) DLT 296  
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 11 of 19 
 
marks must be compared in their entireties. A mark 
should not be dissected or split up into its 
component parts and each part then compared with 
corresponding parts of the conflicting mark to 
determine the likelihood of confusion. It is the 
impression that the mark as a whole creates on the 
average reasonably prudent buyer and not the parts 
thereof, that is important. As the Supreme Court 
observed:“The 
commercial 
impression 
of 
a 
trademark is derived from it as a whole, not from its 
elements separated and considered in detail. For this 
reason it should be considered in its entirety.” The 
anti-dissection rule is based upon a common sense 
observation of customer behavior : the typical 
shopper does not retain all of the individual details 
of a composite mark in his or her mind, but retains 
only an overall, general impression created by the 
composite as a whole. It is the overall impression 
created by the mark from the ordinary shopper's 
cursory observation in the marketplace that will or 
will not lead to a likelihood of confusion, not the 
impression created from a meticulous comparison 
as expressed in carefully weighed analysis in legal 
briefs. In litigation over the alleged similarity of 
marks, the owner will emphasize the similarities 
and the alleged infringer will emphasize the 
differences. The point is that the two marks should 
not be examined with a microscope to find the 
differences, for this is not the way the average 
purchaser views the marks. To the average buyer, 
the points of similarity are more important that 
minor points of difference. A court should not 
engage in “technical gymnastics” in an attempt to 
find some minor differences between conflicting 
marks. 
 
However, where there are both similarities and differences 
in the marks, there must be weighed against one another to 
see which predominate. 
 
The rationale of the anti-dissection rule is based upon this 
assumption: “An average purchaser does not retain all the 
details of a mark, but rather the mental impression of the 
mark creates in its totality. It has been held to be a violation 
of the anti-dissection rule to focus upon the “prominent” 
feature of a mark and decide likely confusion solely upon 
that feature, ignoring all other elements of the mark. 
Similarly, it is improper to find that one portion of a 
composite mark has no trademark significance, leading to a 
direct comparison between only that which remains.” 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 12 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 12 of 19 
 
21.  
The view of the author makes it scintillatingly clear, 
beyond pale of doubt, that the principle of „anti dissection‟ does 
not impose an absolute embargo upon the consideration of the 
constituent elements of a composite mark. The said elements may 
be viewed as a preliminary step on the way to an ultimate 
determination of probable customer reaction to the conflicting 
composites as a whole. Thus, the principle of „anti-dissection‟ and 
identification of „dominant mark‟ are not antithetical to one 
another and if viewed in a holistic perspective, the said principles 
rather compliment each other. 
 
23.  
It is also settled that while a trademark is supposed to be 
looked at in entirety, yet the consideration of a trademark as a 
whole does not condone infringement where less than the entire 
trademark is appropriated. It is therefore not improper to identify 
elements or features of the marks that are more or less important 
for purpose of analysis in cases of composite marks. 
 
26.  
Dominant features are significant because they attract 
attention and consumers are more likely to remember and rely on 
them for purposes of identification of the product. Usually, the 
dominant portion of a mark is that which has the greater strength or 
carries more weight. Descriptive or generic components, having 
little or no source identifying significance, are generally less 
significant in the analysis. However, words that are arbitrary and 
distinct possess greater strength and are thus accorded greater 
protection. [Autozone, Inc. v. Tandy Corporation11]” 
(Emphasis in original) 
 
Where, therefore, part of a composite mark is dominant, another mark, 
which copies or replicates that dominant part, may infringe.  As South 
India Beverages9, this caveat does not violate the “anti dissection 
rule” statutorily engrafted in Section 17(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 
as it merely identifies that part of the whole mark which, being 
dominant, confers, to the whole mark as registered, distinctiveness and 
exclusivity.   
 
16. 
Where a family of marks is involved, as in the present case, the 
identification of the dominant part is greatly simplified.  The very 
moniker that I have chosen to impart to the registered marks of the 
plaintiff – the „NOW‟-family – itself identifies „NOW‟ as the 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 13 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 13 of 19 
 
dominant part of the mark family.  It is but obvious that a viewer who 
views the TIMES NOW, ET NOW, ROMEDY NOW, MIRROR 
NOW and MOVIES NOW channels would identify NOW as the 
distinctive common feature of all the marks and, therefore, their 
“dominant” part. 
 
17. 
The sequitur is obvious.  If such a viewer, endowed with the 
mythical attributes of an average intelligence and an imperfect 
recollection, were to come across another channel, providing similar 
services, with a title of which „NOW‟ is the latter part, there is every 
likelihood of his regarding the channel as part of the petitioner‟s 
repertoire, or at least as having an association with the NOW-family 
of channels of the petitioner.   
 
18. 
It is also important in this context to note the exact features of 
the impugned mark. Though the defendant had the impugned mark 
registered as a single word „VNOW‟, the word „VNOW‟ is unknown 
to the English language.  It has no etymological meaning unlike, for 
example, „KNOW‟ or „SNOW‟.  A person who has to pronounce the 
impugned mark would, therefore, pronounce it „vee-now‟. The 
„NOW‟ part of the impugned mark would be separately and distinctly 
intoned by any person who seeks to pronounce the impugned mark  
and, therefore, would have its own distinct identity even if it is not 
used as a separate word, as has been used by the plaintiff in respect of 
its „NOW‟-family of marks.  
 
19. 
The usage, by the defendant, of a different colour for the 
„NOW‟ part of the impugned 
  mark further emphasizes its 
                                                                                                                   
11 174 F. Supp. 2d 718, 725 (M.D. Tenn. 2001) 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 14 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 14 of 19 
 
distinct identity, even as part of the whole 
 mark.  Thus, even as 
seen visually, „NOW‟ forms a distinct and separately identifiable part 
of the defendant‟s impugned mark.  In that view of the matter, the 
mere fact that the impugned 
 mark is written as one word and 
not as two words would not make any difference to the issue at hand.  
 
20. 
Do, then, the various sub-sections of Section 11, as invoked by 
Ms Jha, apply, to disentitle the impugned 
 mark to registration 
under the Trade Marks Act? 
 
21. 
Section 11(1)(b): 
 
21.1 Section 11(1)(b) proscribes registration of a trade mark which 
(i) is similar to an earlier trade mark and (ii) is used in respect of 
goods or services which are identical or similar to the earlier mark.  
Where these elements coalesce, and (iii) where it is found that, by 
such usage, a likelihood of confusion, or a likelihood of association, 
by the public, with the earlier trade mark, exists, the mark cannot be 
registered.  
 
21.2 I have already held that the usage of „NOW‟ as the latter part of 
the impugned 
 mark renders the mark similar to the „NOW‟-
family of marks registered in favour of the plaintiff, as „NOW‟ 
constitutes the dominant part thereof.  Where the dominant parts of 
two marks are identical, the marks have necessarily to be regarded as 
similar.  The services, of which the petitioner seeks deletion from the 
array of services in respect of which the impugned 
 mark stands 
registered, are identical to the services rendered by the plaintiff, in 
respect of which the marks in the „NOW‟-family stand registered.  
There is, therefore, every likelihood of an unwary member of the 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 15 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 15 of 19 
 
public, who comes across the services of the defendant under the 
impugned 
 mark, to presume an association with the petitioner 
or even regard the services as part of the petitioners oeuvre. The 
ingredients of Section 11(1)(b), therefore, stand satisfied.  
 
22. 
Sections 11(2) and (3) vis-à-vis Section 11(5)12:   
 
22.1 Section 11(2) of the Trade Marks Act proscribes registration of 
a mark which is identical with, or similar to, an earlier trade mark, 
even if the goods or services, in respect of which its registration is 
sought, are different from those in respect of which the earlier mark 
stands registered, provided (i) the earlier mark is a well known trade 
mark within the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade Marks Act 
and (ii) the use of the later mark without due cause would take unfair 
advantage of, or be detrimental to, the distinctive character or repute 
of the earlier mark.  Section 11(3) proscribes registration of any trade 
mark if its use in India is liable to be prevented by the law of passing 
off or by the law of copyright.   
 
22.2 Section 11(5), however, obviates the necessity of examining the 
applicability either of Section 11(2) or of Section 11(3).  Section 11(5) 
clearly holds that a mark would not be refused registration on the 
grounds specified in sub-sections (2) and (3) of Section 11 unless an 
objection, on one of the grounds envisaged by Section 11(2) of 
Section 11(3), is raised in an opposition proceedings by the proprietor 
of the earlier trade mark, i.e., in the present case, the petitioner.  
 
22.3 It is an undisputed position that no objection relatable to Section 
                                          
12 (5)  
A trade mark shall not be refused registration on the grounds specified in sub-sections (2) and (3), 
unless objection on any one or more of those grounds is raised in opposition proceedings by the proprietor of

By:KAMLA RAWAT

12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 16 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 16 of 19 
 
11(2) or Section 11(3) was raised in opposition proceedings by the 
petitioner at or before the registration of the impugned 
 mark in 
favour of the respondent. 
 
22.4 Ms. Mamta Rani Jha sought to contend that Section 11(5) 
would apply only at the time when the mark is originally registered 
and that the rigour of the provision would not operate to dilute the 
applicability of Section 11(2) or 11(3) at the stage when cancellation 
of a registered mark is sought.  I am unable to agree. 
 
22.5 Once a mark is registered, Section 57 confers, on a person 
aggrieved by the registration, the right to seek its cancellation and 
consequent rectification of the register.  The circumstances in which 
cancellation and rectification can be sought are circumscribed within 
sub-sections (1) and (2) of Section 57.  Section 57(1) envisages 
cancellation or variation of the entry in the register where there is any 
contravention or failure to observe a condition entered on the register.  
That provision, quite clearly, does not apply to the present case. 
 
22.6 Section 57(2) envisages removal of a mark from the register 
where either (i) the entry is made in the register without sufficient 
cause or (ii) the entry is wrongly remaining in the register or (iii) there 
is any error or defect in the entry in the register.  If one or more of 
these three exigencies exists, the mark can either be expunged or 
varied from the register.  
 
22.7 Of these three exigencies, the only exigency which could apply 
in the present case is the second i.e., that the defendant‟s mark is 
                                                                                                                   
the earlier trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 17 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 17 of 19 
 
continuing to wrongly remain in the register. Etymologically, a mark 
could be regarded as “wrongly remaining on the register” either (i) 
where it was correctly registered but, owing to intervening 
circumstances, its continuance on the register is impermissible, or (ii) 
where its very registration was bad, as the mark was non-registerable 
on account of one or more of the grounds envisaged in Sections 9 and 
11 of the Trade Marks Act.   I need not concern myself with the first 
of these two exigencies, as Ms Mamta Rani Jha has squarely relied on 
Section 11(1), (2) and (3), which imperil the very entitlement of the 
mark to registration, to canvass her case.  Ms Jha‟s submission is, 
therefore, that, as the impugned 
 mark was not entitled to 
registration and was, nonetheless, registered, its continuance on the 
register was impermissible in law; in other words, that it was 
“wrongly remaining on the register”.  
 
22.8 The entitlement of the impugned mark to registration and the 
entitlement of the opponent of the mark to seek its cancellation or 
variation, thus, statutorily dovetail into one another.  To be able to 
successfully contend that the respondent‟s 
 mark was liable to 
be cancelled or varied, Ms Jha would have to successfully invoke one 
or more of the sub-sections of Section 9 or Section 11.  All the rigours 
which statutorily apply to these provisions, and their invocability, 
would also, therefore, apply to Ms Jha‟s attempt to do so.    
 
22.9 I am, therefore, of the considered opinion that Section 11(5) 
does not apply differently at the stage when the application for 
registration of a mark is under consideration and when an application 
for rectification of the register and removal of a mark therefrom, under 
Section 57(2), has been made.  Section 11(5) operates as a proviso to 
Sections 11(2) and 11(3), by excepting their applicability to cases in 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 18 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 18 of 19 
 
which, at the time of consideration of the mark for registration, no 
opposition predicated on the said provisions is raised.  If, therefore, no 
opposition predicated on Section 11(2) or 11(3) was raised by the 
petition when the defendant‟s 
 mark was being considered for 
registration, the mark could not have been refused registration under 
Section 11(2) or 11(3).  The corollary would, therefore, be that the 
grant of registration to the 
 mark cannot be said to be improper, 
illegal or vitiated as being violative of Section 11(2) or 11(3).   
 
22.10 As, admittedly, no opposition, predicated on Section 11(2) or 
11(3) was raised by the petitioner at the time when the defendant‟s  
 mark was proceeding to registration, the petitioner cannot urge 
Section 11(2) or 11(3) as a ground to seek its cancellation or variation. 
 
23. 
In any event, as the grant of registration to the impugned mark 
of the defendant has already been found by me to be violative of 
Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, a clear case for rectification 
of the register and variation of the impugned mark as sought by the 
petitioner, so as to remove the handicap of Section 11(1)(b), is made 
out.   
 
Conclusion 
 
24. 
Resultantly, the Registration No. 2948252 dated 23rd April 2015 
granted to the impugned 
 mark in favour of the defendant in 
class 38 shall stand varied and, consequently, rectified by deleting, 
from the services in respect of which the impugned mark is registered,

& Content, Electronic Communication Services, Providing Access To

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
This is a court document from the High Court of Delhi, specifically Case No. C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021, Benet, Coleman and Company Limited v. Vnow Technologies Private Limited.

**Case Summary:**

* The petition is for rectification under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act 1999 to remove a registered mark "VNOW" from Vnow Technologies Private Limited.
* The petitioner, Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited, claims that the respondent's registration of the mark was in contravention of the conditions entered on the register.
* The learned Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) issued notice to the respondent on September 28, 2020, but they remained absent despite service.
* The matter was transferred to the High Court of Delhi and listed for hearing several times between January 14, 2022, and January 16, 2023.

**Facts:**

* Respondent 1 has continuously remained absent despite being served notice by both the IPAB and the High Court.
* Petitioner is the registered proprietor of a trade mark related to digital data and communication services.

**Decisions:**

* The High Court proceeds to dispose of the petition based on the record, without hearing from the respondent.

**Parties:**

* Benet, Coleman and Company Limited (petitioner)
* Vnow Technologies Private Limited (respondent 1)

**Dates:**

* September 28, 2020: IPAB issues notice to respondent
* January 14, 2022 - January 16, 2023: Matter listed before the High Court

**Source:** Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.pdf

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Section: Background and Facts from Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd (2023)**

Source: [PDF document from Courts.bombayhigh.nic.in](https://courts.bombayhigh.nic.in/Judgments/PDF/2023/DHC/001066.pdf)

**Legal Proceedings:** This is a trademark infringement case filed by Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited (BCCL) against Vnow Technologies Private Limited and another defendant.

**Facts:**

* BCCL claims to have adopted the mark "NOW" as part of its various trademarks, including TIMES NOW (2006), ET NOW (2009), MOVIES NOW (2010), ROMEDY NOW (2013), and MIRROR NOW (launched in 2015 and rebranded from MAGIC BRICKS NOW).
* The petitioner has been using the "NOW" mark in various services, including television broadcasting, radio broadcasting, cable television broadcasting, internet and websites, online forums, satellite transmission, computer-aided transmission of messages and images, and providing user access to global computer networks.

**Arguments:**

* BCCL argues that it has continuously used the "NOW" mark as part of its various trademarks since 2004.
* The petitioner is seeking an injunction against Vnow Technologies Private Limited for trademark infringement and damages.

**Decisions:**
The document does not provide information on any decisions made in this case, but rather presents the background and facts of the dispute.

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
The content of Page 3 from the PDF "28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.(2023/DHC/001066)" is as follows:

The court lists out four trade marks registered by the plaintiff, namely:

1. TIMES NOW: covering various broadcasting services, telecommunications, and user access to a global computer network.
2. ET NOW: similar services as TIME NOW.
3. MOVIES NOW: including television and radio broadcasting, cable television broadcasting, satellite transmission, and telecommunications services.
4. MIRROR NOW: covering telecommunications, television broadcasting, cellular telephone communication, internet and websites, and digital broadcasting.

The plaintiff has alleged infringement of these trade marks by the defendant, VNow Technologies Private Limited.

The only relevant legal fact mentioned is the registration of these trade marks by the plaintiff.

**Source:** PDF: "28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.(2023/DHC/001066)"

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Legal Document: Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.*

**Case Information**

* Court: High Court of Delhi
* Case Number: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021
* Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001066

**Parties**

* Plaintiff: Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited (petitioner)
* Defendant: Vnow Technologies Private Limited and Anr.

**Facts**

The petitioner seeks rectification of the Trade Marks Register by restricting the registration of the respondent's mark "NOW" to specific services. The petitioner alleges that the use of "NOW" in the respondent's mark would lead to confusion among the public, given the petitioner's registered marks involving "NOW". The petitioner submits that an unwary viewer would associate the impugned mark with the petitioner's registered marks.

**Legal Arguments**

The petitioner argues under Section 113(1), (2), (3)(a) and (10) of the Trade Marks Act, read with Section 29, citing relative grounds for refusal of registration. The petitioner contends that the respondent's continued registration of the impugned mark would be violative of the law.

**Decision**

The court has not made a final decision on the matter as it is still under consideration.

**Source:** Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.. pdf

Relative grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
Save as provided in Section 12, a trade mark shall not be registered if, because of –  
(a)  
its identity with an earlier trade mark and similarity of goods or services 
covered by the trade mark; or 
(b)  
its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or similarity of the goods 
or services covered by the trade mark, 
there exists a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public, which includes the likelihood of 
association with the earlier trade mark. 
(2)  
A trade mark which –  
(a)  
is identical with or similar to an earlier trade mark; and 
(b) 
is to be registered for goods or services which are not similar to those for which 
the earlier trade mark is registered in the name of a different proprietor, 
shall not be registered if or to the extent the earlier trade mark is a well-known trade mark in India 
and the use of the later mark without due cause would take unfair advantage of or be detrimental to 
the distinctive character or repute of the earlier trade mark. 
(3)  
A trade mark shall not be registered if, or to the extent that, its use in India is liable to be 
prevented –  
(a)  
by virtue of any law in particular the law of passing off protecting an 
unregistered trade mark used in the course of trade; or 
(b)  
by virtue of law of copyright. 
***** 
 
(10)  
While considering an application for registration of a trade mark and opposition filed in 
respect thereof, the Registrar shall –  
(i)   
protect a well-known trade mark against the identical or similar trade marks; 
(ii)  
take into consideration the bad faith involved either of the applicant or the 
opponent affecting the right relating to the trade mark.

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the provided PDF:

**Case Details:**

* Case No.: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001066

**Arguments and Decision:**

On page 8, the court discusses the plaintiff's "NOW centric" marks and how proprietorial rights can emerge from a family of marks held by a registrant.

The court cites two previous judgments:

* Amar Singh Chawal Wala v. Shree Vardhman Rice & General Mills ( ILR (2009)VI Delhi 399)
* Kirorimal Kashiram Marketing v. Shree Sita Chawal Udyog Mill (AIR 1963 SC 449)

The court holds that even if part of the marks are common, proprietorial rights can still be recognized.

**PDF Source:**

Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd. (2023/DHC/001066) - PDF available on request
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 8 of 19 
 
„NOW centric‟ marks of the plaintiff, merits acceptance.  
 
11. 
That proprietorial rights can emerge even from a family of 
marks held by a registrant, in which part of the marks may be 
common, stands recognized by a Division Bench of this Court in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala v. Shree Vardhman Rice & General 
Mills4, which has been followed by another Division Bench in 
Kirorimal Kashiram Marketing  v. Shree Sita Chawal Udyog Mill5. 
One may usefully reproduce, in this context, para 18 of the report in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala4: 
“18.  
It is not possible to agree with the reasoning of the learned 
Single Judge that the word QILLA is not associated with rice and 
therefore no ordinary purchaser of rice would associate the 
Defendant's mark as that of the Plaintiffs. It is plain from the 
pleadings that the Plaintiff has been using the words QILLA 
consistently in connection with the rice being sold by them with 
only the first word indicating the colour viz., GOLDEN, LAL or 
NEELA. It must be held that the Plaintiff has been able to prima 
facie show that it has developed a ‘family of marks’ and that by 
merely changing the first word from GOLDEN, LAL or NEELA to 
the word HARA there is every possibility of confusion being caused 
both in trade and in the mind of any person desiring to purchase 
rice. Likewise the use of the picture or depiction of a fort in the 
background on the label/packing of the rice is also likely to cause 
confusion in the mind of the purchaser and in the trade that the 
product being sold by the Defendants are in fact those 
manufactured by the Plaintiff.” 
(Emphasis supplied) 
 
In a similar vein, the High Court of Bombay, in Neon Laboratories 
Ltd v. Themis Medicare Ltd6, held the “XYLOX family of marks” 
comprising XYLOX 2%, XYLOX HEAVY, XYLOX GEL, XYLOX 
ADRENALINE and XYLOX 2% Jelly to be infringing the “LOX 
family of marks” comprising LOX 2% ADRENALINE, LOX 4%, 
LOX 5%, LOX HEAVY 5%, LOX VISCOUS, LOXALPRIN, 
LOXALPRY, LOXIMLA, PLOX and RILOX. 
                                          
4 ILR (2009)VI Delhi 399  
5 AIR 1963 SC 449

Based on page 9 of the provided PDF (28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.pdf), here are the key points:

**Case Information:**

* Case number: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001066

**Legal Facts and Proceedings:**

* The case involves "the NOW family of marks", which includes TIMES NOW, ET NOW, ROMEDY NOW, MOVIES NOW, and MIRROR NOW.
* Section 17(1) clarifies that the proprietorial rights conferred by registration are for the mark as a whole, not individual parts.

**Notable Quotes:**

* "The registrations held by the petitioner in the ‘NOW’ family of marks confers on it, rights to claim exclusivity in respect of each of the marks as a whole, and not in respect of the ‘NOW’ part of each of the marks." (para 14)
* "Section 17(2)(a) makes matters clearer... by disentitling exclusivity in respect of part of a mark which is registered as a whole. This has, over time, come to be known as “the anti-dissection rule”."

**PDF Source:**
(28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.pdf)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 9 of 19 
 
12. 
The „NOW‟-centric „TIMES NOW‟, „ET NOW‟, „MOVIES 
NOW‟, „MIRROR NOW‟ and „ROMEDY NOW‟ marks constitute a 
“family of marks” within the meaning of the concept as understood in 
Amar Singh Chawal Wala4 and Neon Laboratories6, especially as 
they cover services provided in the same Class 38.   I will refer to the 
registered trade marks of the plaintiff, therefore, as “the „NOW‟ 
family of marks” hereinafter, instead of “the „NOW‟-centric marks”. 
 
13. 
Section 17(1)7 clarifies that the proprietorial rights conferred by 
registration is for the mark as a whole.  In other words, the rights 
conferred on the petitioner by the registrations held by it in respect of 
the NOW family of marks are over the TIMES NOW, ET NOW, 
ROMEDY NOW, MOVIES NOW and MIRROR NOW marks as a 
whole in each case, and not for the mark „NOW‟ per se.  Section 
17(2)(a)8 makes matters clearer, by disentitling exclusivity in respect 
of part of a mark which is registered as a whole.  This has, over time, 
come to be known as “the anti-dissection rule”.  
 
14. 
The registrations held by the petitioner in the „NOW‟ family of 
marks confers, therefore, on it, rights to claim exclusivity in respect of 
each of the marks as a whole, and not in respect of the „NOW‟ part of 
each of the marks.

Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
8 (2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark –  
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-distinctive 
character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the whole of 
the trade mark so registered.

The anti-dissection rule is, however, subject to a caveat, 
elucidated thus by Pradeep Nandrajog, J. (as he then was), speaking 
for a Division Bench of this Court, in South India Beverages Pvt Ltd 
v. General Mills Marketing Inc.9: 
“19.  
Though it bears no reiteration that while a mark is to be 
considered in entirety, yet it is permissible to accord more or less 
importance or „dominance‟ to a particular portion or element of a 
mark in cases of composite marks. Thus, a particular element of a 
composite mark which enjoys greater prominence vis-à-vis other 
constituent elements, may be termed as a „dominant mark‟. 
 
20.  
At this juncture it would be apposite to refer to a recent 
decision of this Court reported as Stiefel Laborataries v. Ajanta 
Pharma Ltd10.  The Court whilst expounding upon the principle of 
„anti-dissection‟ cited with approval the views of the eminent 
author on the subject comprised in his authoritative treatise-
McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition. It was 
observed: 
 
“41.  
The anti-dissection rule which is under these 
circumstances required to be applied in India is really based 
upon nature of customer. It has been rightly set out in 
McCarthy on Trademarks and Unfair Competition about 
the said rule particularly in Para 23.15 which is reproduced 
hereunder: 
 
23.15 Comparing 
Marks: 
Differences v. Similarities 
 
[1]  
The Anti-Dissection Rule 
 
[a]  
Compare 
composites 
as 
a 
Whole 
: 
Conflicting composite marks are to be compared by 
looking at them as a whole, rather than breaking the 
marks 
up 
into 
their 
component 
parts 
for 
comparison. This is the “anti dissection” rule. The 
rationale for the rule is that the commercial 
impression of a composite trademark on an ordinary 
prospective buyer is created by the mark as a whole, 
not by its component parts. However, it is not a 
violation of the anti-dissection rule to view the 
component parts of conflicting composite marks as 
a preliminary step on the way to an ultimate 
determination of probable customer reaction to the 
conflicting composites as a whole. Thus, conflicting

nodes.title: Page 11
nodes.summary:
This is a judgment from the High Court of Delhi in the case of Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited v. Vnow Technologies Private Limited.

**Key points from page 11 (PDF source: 28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.pdf)**

The court discusses the "anti-dissection rule" regarding trademarks, which states that a mark should be viewed as a whole rather than dissected into individual parts. The focus is on the overall impression created by the mark on an average reasonably prudent buyer.

Key quotes:

* "The commercial impression of a trademark is derived from it as a whole, not from its elements separated and considered in detail."
* "To the average buyer, the points of similarity are more important than minor points of difference."

The court emphasizes that when comparing marks, courts should not focus on technical details but rather consider the overall impression created by each mark.

Note: The PDF source is a judgment from a case numbered 2023/DHC/001066 and bears a digital signature dated February 15, 2023.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001066 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021  
Page 11 of 19 
 
marks must be compared in their entireties. A mark 
should not be dissected or split up into its 
component parts and each part then compared with 
corresponding parts of the conflicting mark to 
determine the likelihood of confusion. It is the 
impression that the mark as a whole creates on the 
average reasonably prudent buyer and not the parts 
thereof, that is important. As the Supreme Court 
observed:“The 
commercial 
impression 
of 
a 
trademark is derived from it as a whole, not from its 
elements separated and considered in detail. For this 
reason it should be considered in its entirety.” The 
anti-dissection rule is based upon a common sense 
observation of customer behavior : the typical 
shopper does not retain all of the individual details 
of a composite mark in his or her mind, but retains 
only an overall, general impression created by the 
composite as a whole. It is the overall impression 
created by the mark from the ordinary shopper's 
cursory observation in the marketplace that will or 
will not lead to a likelihood of confusion, not the 
impression created from a meticulous comparison 
as expressed in carefully weighed analysis in legal 
briefs. In litigation over the alleged similarity of 
marks, the owner will emphasize the similarities 
and the alleged infringer will emphasize the 
differences. The point is that the two marks should 
not be examined with a microscope to find the 
differences, for this is not the way the average 
purchaser views the marks. To the average buyer, 
the points of similarity are more important that 
minor points of difference. A court should not 
engage in “technical gymnastics” in an attempt to 
find some minor differences between conflicting 
marks. 
 
However, where there are both similarities and differences 
in the marks, there must be weighed against one another to 
see which predominate. 
 
The rationale of the anti-dissection rule is based upon this 
assumption: “An average purchaser does not retain all the 
details of a mark, but rather the mental impression of the 
mark creates in its totality. It has been held to be a violation 
of the anti-dissection rule to focus upon the “prominent” 
feature of a mark and decide likely confusion solely upon 
that feature, ignoring all other elements of the mark. 
Similarly, it is improper to find that one portion of a 
composite mark has no trademark significance, leading to a 
direct comparison between only that which remains.” 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:15.02.2023
12:48:02

The provided text appears to be page 12 from a PDF file regarding a trademark dispute case "Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd." [2023/DHC/001066] (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021). Here is the summary:

**Key points:**

* The principle of "anti-dissection" does not impose an absolute embargo on considering the constituent elements of a composite mark.
* Identifying dominant features of a mark is essential for determining probable customer reaction and potential infringement.
* A dominant part of a composite mark can confer distinctiveness and exclusivity to the whole mark.

**Case references:**

* Autozone, Inc. v. Tandy Corporation (re arbitration words)
* South India Beverages (mentioning "anti-dissection rule" in Section 17(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act)

The text mentions the plaintiff, Bennet, Coleman and Company Ltd., challenging Vnow Technologies Private Limited's alleged trademark infringement.

Page 12 of 19 
 
21.  
The view of the author makes it scintillatingly clear, 
beyond pale of doubt, that the principle of „anti dissection‟ does 
not impose an absolute embargo upon the consideration of the 
constituent elements of a composite mark. The said elements may 
be viewed as a preliminary step on the way to an ultimate 
determination of probable customer reaction to the conflicting 
composites as a whole. Thus, the principle of „anti-dissection‟ and 
identification of „dominant mark‟ are not antithetical to one 
another and if viewed in a holistic perspective, the said principles 
rather compliment each other. 
 
23.  
It is also settled that while a trademark is supposed to be 
looked at in entirety, yet the consideration of a trademark as a 
whole does not condone infringement where less than the entire 
trademark is appropriated. It is therefore not improper to identify 
elements or features of the marks that are more or less important 
for purpose of analysis in cases of composite marks. 
 
26.  
Dominant features are significant because they attract 
attention and consumers are more likely to remember and rely on 
them for purposes of identification of the product. Usually, the 
dominant portion of a mark is that which has the greater strength or 
carries more weight. Descriptive or generic components, having 
little or no source identifying significance, are generally less 
significant in the analysis. However, words that are arbitrary and 
distinct possess greater strength and are thus accorded greater 
protection. [Autozone, Inc. v. Tandy Corporation11]” 
(Emphasis in original) 
 
Where, therefore, part of a composite mark is dominant, another mark, 
which copies or replicates that dominant part, may infringe.  As South 
India Beverages9, this caveat does not violate the “anti dissection 
rule” statutorily engrafted in Section 17(2)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 
as it merely identifies that part of the whole mark which, being 
dominant, confers, to the whole mark as registered, distinctiveness and 
exclusivity.   
 
16. 
Where a family of marks is involved, as in the present case, the 
identification of the dominant part is greatly simplified.  The very 
moniker that I have chosen to impart to the registered marks of the 
plaintiff – the „NOW‟-family – itself identifies „NOW‟ as the

Here is a summary of page 13 from the PDF source:

In Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd., the court analyzes whether the defendant's mark "VNOW" infringes on the plaintiff's "NOW" family of marks (e.g. TIMES NOW, ET NOW).

**Key Points:**

1. The court finds that "NOW" is the distinctive common feature of the plaintiff's marks, and would be identified as such by a viewer.
2. If another channel with a similar title has "NOW" as its latter part, there is likelihood that viewers will associate it with the plaintiff's repertoire or have an association with the NOW-family of channels.
3. The defendant's mark "VNOW" is unknown to the English language and lacks etymological meaning, but would be pronounced as "vee-now", with the "NOW" part being separately intoned.

**Relevant Court Decision:**

The court references a US case (11 174 F.Supp.2d 718) in support of its reasoning.

Source: Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd..pdf (2023/DHC/001066)

Court proceedings are ongoing in the High Court of Delhi regarding trade mark infringement.

On page 14, the judge addresses whether the impugned mark is similar to the plaintiff's earlier marks. The judge finds that the word "NOW" forms a distinct and separately identifiable part of the defendant's impugned mark. Although the impugned mark is written as one word, this does not alter its similarity.

The judge then considers Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, which prohibits registration where a mark is similar to an earlier trade mark and used in respect of identical or similar goods/services, leading to a likelihood of confusion or association with the earlier mark. The judge holds that the impugned mark is similar to the plaintiff's "NOW"-family marks due to its dominant part being identical. Furthermore, the services offered by the defendant are identical to those offered by the plaintiff.

nodes.title: Page 15
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 15 from the provided PDF:

The court discusses Sections 11(2) and (3) of the Trade Marks Act, which prohibit registration of a mark that is identical or similar to an earlier trade mark, even if the goods or services are different. Section 11(3) also prohibits registration if use in India would be prevented by law of passing off or copyright.

Section 11(5), however, provides that objection under Sections 11(2) and (3) is not mandatory unless raised by the proprietor of the earlier trade mark in opposition proceedings.

The court notes that no such objection has been raised by the petitioner, Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited. Therefore, under Section 11(5), no objection arises under Sections 11(2) or (3).

This interpretation highlights the importance of examining whether an objection was raised by the proprietor of the earlier trade mark in opposition proceedings before refusing registration.

Source: 28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd..pdf

**Case:** Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/001066

On this page, the judge, HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C. HARI SHANKAR, deliberates on Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. In particular, he addresses whether sub-sections (2) or (3) are applicable in opposition proceedings.

**Key Points:**

* Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act confers the right to seek cancellation and rectification of a registered mark.
* The court holds that Section 11(5) applies at the time of original registration, not at the stage of cancellation.
* The defendant's mark was registered without sufficient cause, making it eligible for removal from the register under Section 57(2).

**Relevant Legal Provisions:**

* Section 11(2) and (3)
* Section 57(1) and (2) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999

would apply only at the time when the mark is originally registered 
and that the rigour of the provision would not operate to dilute the

22.5 Once a mark is registered, Section 57 confers, on a person 
aggrieved by the registration, the right to seek its cancellation and 
consequent rectification of the register.  The circumstances in which 
cancellation and rectification can be sought are circumscribed within 
sub-sections (1) and (2) of Section 57.  Section 57(1) envisages 
cancellation or variation of the entry in the register where there is any 
contravention or failure to observe a condition entered on the register.  
That provision, quite clearly, does not apply to the present case. 
 
22.6 Section 57(2) envisages removal of a mark from the register 
where either (i) the entry is made in the register without sufficient

is any error or defect in the entry in the register.  If one or more of 
these three exigencies exists, the mark can either be expunged or 
varied from the register.  
 
22.7 Of these three exigencies, the only exigency which could apply 
in the present case is the second i.e., that the defendant‟s mark is

nodes.title: Page 17
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 17 from the PDF:

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi ruled in favor of Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited (plaintiff) against Vnow Technologies Private Limited (defendant). The case was filed under C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021.

Ms. Mamta Rani Jha, representing the plaintiff, argued that the defendant's mark was not entitled to registration under Section 11(1), (2), and (3) of the Trade Marks Act. The court agreed with this argument, stating that if a mark is not entitled to registration, its continuance on the register is impermissible in law.

The court held that the entitlement of the impugned mark to registration and the entitlement of the opponent (plaintiff) to seek cancellation or variation statutorily dovetail into one another. To successfully contend for cancellation or variation, the plaintiff must invoke one or more of the sub-sections of Section 9 or Section 11.

The case is **2023/DHC/001066** and can be found in the PDF source Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd..

where its very registration was bad, as the mark was non-registerable

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Court Decision Summary**

**Case Details:**

* Case Name: Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001066
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date: February 14, 2023

**Background:**
The petitioner, Bennet, Coleman and Company Limited, sought to cancel or vary the registration of Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd.'s trademark, impugned mark #2948252, due to alleged violation of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Court Decision:**

* The court held that since no opposition was raised by the petitioner at the time of registration, they cannot now raise objections under Sections 11(2) or 11(3).
* However, the grant of registration was found to be violative of Section 11(1)(b), which relates to deceptive similarity.
* Consequently, the court ordered variation and rectification of the register by restraining the defendant's mark from including services like transmission, reception & sharing of downloadable digital data & content.

**Judgment:**

* The Registration No. 2948252 was varied and rectified to restrict the defendant's mark to "smart security solution devices, power bank, chats or social networking services or conferences or webinars".
* The petition was allowed accordingly.
* Judgment was uploaded on the website of the court within 24 hours.

**Source:** Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd. (28. Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd..pdf)

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 18 from the PDF:

**Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd**

Page 18 discusses the implications of Section 11(2) and (3) of the Trade Marks Act on the registration of the defendant's mark.

* If no opposition was raised based on these provisions when the mark was being considered for registration, it cannot be refused on those grounds.
* Therefore, the grant of registration to the mark cannot be deemed improper or illegal if no opposition was raised on Section 11(2) or (3).
* However, since the plaintiff did not raise any opposition at that time, they may not now argue these provisions as a ground for seeking cancellation or variation.
* Nonetheless, given the finding of violation of Section 11(1)(b), the register shall be rectified and the impugned mark varied to remove the handicap caused by this provision.

**PDF Source:** Bennet, Coleman and Company v. Vnow Technologies Pvt Ltd..pdf (28 pages)

**Key Facts:**

* C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 117/2021, Delhi High Court
* Registration No. 2948252 dated 23rd April 2015
* Section 11(1)(b), Trade Marks Act
